Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Story: It’s Saturday afternoon, and my phone buzzes with a message from Mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend! Call us when you can.” I glance at the clock—just past three. I haven’t spoken to my parents all week, and guilt tugs at me. I know they expect me to check in, to share a little about my life, to remind them I’m still their kid even though I’m busy. But my headset is already on, and the office is tense. It’s the last day of the quarter, and every call counts. My manager’s voice echoes in my head: “We need five more sales to hit target. No distractions.” If we don’t make it, the whole team loses out on bonuses, and I can’t afford that. My phone buzzes again—Dad this time, a simple “Miss you.” I stare at the screen, torn. My family wants to hear my voice, but my job demands my full attention. My heart pounds as I weigh the phone in my hand, caught between being a good child and a responsible employee, not sure which role to answer first.
